bibl.author: William Sloane Kennedy
bibl.title: William Sloane Kennedy to Walt Whitman, 16 January 1885
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

body.p: I send you by this mail my paper—"The New Ars Poetica"
I want you to read it, &, if you think best, ask McKay to bring it out for us.

I have a strong & even strange feeling of the educative and epoch-making nature of your style (poetical); & I am confident that my essay will do great good. I want all the chief American & especially the English poets to have copies. Nothing in the world, I believe, stands so much in
the way of the greater sale of yr your "Leaves" as the idea among people that your style is ridiculous & unpoetical. The laugh, I find, is always raised by this the first thing. If they cd could have good authority or rendered reason & proof that the style was true to nature & good in itself, other difficulties wd would easily melt away.

I have examined all literary sources, but have had to work out the subject—in the main, by slow & painful original steps. What do you think of my performance? I wish the libret might even be bound. It ought to sell a small edition. Can you interest some moneyed fellow in it?

postscript.p:
Can't you write me something yourself on the all important subject? Come: that
wd would sell the brochure sure. Write it to me, say, in the form of a letter which I then print by yr your permission. Do you see?

Do exert yourself in the matter if you feel able. I believe it wd would give you a money return. We shd get people to talking at a great rate. Especially if you are quoted as saying something philosophical on the subject; something new, in addition to that in preface & yr your first quarto.
